claim: Turkey, an EU country, has a majority of people who are Muslim.

supporting.text: Turkey is not a member of the European Union, so the claim is false by definition.

attacks.text: Turkey is not a member of the European Union, so the claim is false by definition.
Turkey has been a candidate for EU membership since 1999 and is part of the EU Customs Union, which creates a close association.
Many EU policies and agreements already apply to Turkey, making it de facto integrated in some aspects.
Candidate status does not equate to membership, and the Customs Union is not the same as full EU accession.
De facto integration does not change the legal status of Turkey as a non-EU member.
The EU has suspended accession talks with Turkey due to democratic backsliding, further distancing it from membership.
Legal status is determined by treaties, and Turkey has not signed the EU accession treaty.

supporting.text: Turkey has a predominantly Muslim population, with over 99% of its citizens identifying as Muslim.

attacks.text: Turkey has a predominantly Muslim population, with over 99% of its citizens identifying as Muslim.
Official statistics may not account for secular or non-religious individuals who do not openly identify as Muslim due to societal pressures.
The 99% figure is outdated and does not reflect recent demographic shifts, including increasing secularization among younger generations.
Independent surveys confirm that self-reported Muslim identity remains consistently high, even among younger Turks.
Recent census data still shows over 95% of the population identifying as Muslim, indicating minimal change.
Methodological flaws in these surveys may lead to overreporting of Muslim identity due to cultural expectations.

supporting.text: The claim incorrectly assumes Turkey is part of the EU, which it is not, despite its long-standing candidate status.

attacks.text: The claim incorrectly assumes Turkey is part of the EU, which it is not, despite its long-standing candidate status.
Turkey has been an official candidate for EU membership since 1999 and has made significant progress in aligning with EU standards.
Turkey participates in several EU programs and has a customs union with the EU, which blurs the line between membership and non-membership.
Despite progress, Turkey has not met all the Copenhagen criteria required for full EU membership, such as human rights and rule of law reforms.
Participation in EU programs does not equate to membership, as many non-EU countries also participate in such programs.

supporting.text: Turkey's cultural and religious identity is distinct from most EU countries, which are predominantly Christian or secular.

attacks.text: Turkey's cultural and religious identity is distinct from most EU countries, which are predominantly Christian or secular.
Turkey has a secular constitution and government, aligning with the secular principles of many EU countries.
Several EU countries, such as Germany and France, have significant Muslim populations, reducing the distinction.
Despite its secular constitution, Turkey's policies and societal norms are heavily influenced by Islam, unlike most EU nations.
The proportion of Muslims in Turkey is much higher than in any EU country, making its religious identity distinct.

supporting.text: Even if Turkey were an EU member, the claim about its Muslim majority would still be accurate.

attacks.text: Even if Turkey were an EU member, the claim about its Muslim majority would still be accurate.
Turkey is not an EU member, so the claim's premise is false regardless of its Muslim majority.
Religious demographics can change over time, and current data may not reflect future trends.
Turkey's EU accession negotiations have been ongoing, indicating potential future membership.
Statistical surveys consistently show that over 90% of Turkey's population identifies as Muslim.
